children.value: Input text is used in forms that accept short or long answers from users.
Use this to allow users to provide short answers.

<Playground>
  {() => {
    const [age, setAge] = useState("Veintisiete");
    return (
      <InputText
        value={age}
        onChange={setAge}
        name="age"
        placeholder="Age in words"
      />
    );
  }}
</Playground>

You can add your own custom validation messages on a field. However, this
shouldn't replace server-side validation.
are available out of the box.
This includes, but is not limited to:

- A Boolean which, if true, indicates that the input must have a
value.
- The maximum length of the value to accept for this input.
- The minimum length of the value to accept for this input.
- The regex pattern for the input.

- You can pass a callback function as the argument to validate, or
you can pass an object of callback functions to validate all of them.

<Playground>
  {() => {
    return (
      <InputText
        name="age"
        placeholder="What's your age"
        validations={{
          required: {
            value: true,
            message: "You have to tell us your age",
          },
          validate: validations,
        }}
      />
    );
    function validations(val) {
      if (val.length > 0 && !isNaN(val)) {
        return "Type your age in words please.";
      }
      if (val.length >= 10) {
        return "That seems too old.";
      }
      return true;
    }
  }}
</Playground>
